column9: Initiative from the undisclosed GRI (found by the coder but not mentioned in the GRI index table)

column6: Entities included in the organization's sustainability reporting
column7: ANZ Group Holdings Limited is the listed parent company of the ANZ Group. ANZ's banking and certain non-banking businesses are separated into two groups, the ANZ Bank Group and ANZ Non-Bank Group; ANZ ServiceCo was established as an internal service company.

column6: Reporting period, frequency, and contact point
column7: ANZ's report covers all of ANZ Group Holdings Limited's operations worldwide for the financial year 1 October 2022 to 30 September 2023.
ANZ restated its 2023 sustainable solutions target.
KPMG provided external assurance for ANZ's report.

column6: Activities, value chain and other business relationships
column7: ANZ provides banking and financial products and services to over 8.5 million retail and business customers and operates across 29 markets.

column6: Nomination and selection of the highest governance body
column13: ANZ has processes that ensure individuals appointed to relevant senior positions have the appropriate fitness and propriety to discharge their prudential responsibilities properly. The framework is set out in ANZ's Group Fit and Proper Policy. Before a new appointment is made to any of the following positions, the Policy requires assessments to be carried out for each Director, relevant senior executives, and the APRA engagement partner of ANZ's External Auditor.
column20: Fit and Proper Policy, senior position, prudential responsibility

column6: Nomination and selection of the highest governance body
column13: Each new Non-Executive Director receives a letter regarding their appointment and a Director's Deed covering several issues, including indemnity, directors' and officers' liability insurance, the right to obtain independent advice, confidentiality requirements and access to information.
column20: Non-Executive Director, Director's Deed, independent advice

column6: Chair of the highest governance body
column7: Mr Paul O'Sullivan is the chair of ANZ's Board.

column6: Role of the highest governance body in overseeing the management of impacts
column7: The Board oversees ANZ and its sound and prudent management, with specific duties in its Charter.

column6: Delegation of responsibility for managing impacts
column13: ANZ's Employee Code supports ANZ's values and provides ANZ employees with a practical set of guiding principles to help them make fair, balanced and ethical decisions in their day-to-day work. ANZ employees must demonstrate these behaviours and comply with the Code.

column6: Delegation of responsibility for managing impacts
column13: The Board appoints the CEO and certain senior management team members at ANZ, as set out in its Charter. The Board delegates to the CEO, and through the CEO to senior management, via the Board Delegation to Management Policy and the CEO Delegation of Authority Policy, the authority and responsibility to make decisions to achieve ANZ's approved strategies and financial objectives. These Policies are reviewed regularly.
column20: Board Delegation to Management Policy, CEO, senior management

column6: Role of the highest governance body in sustainability reporting
column13: This year, ANZ strengthened its risk culture by improving Risk Culture Survey outcomes across the Group, particularly in recognition and reward for effective risk management. Risk culture is measured annually to support the Board in forming a view of ANZ's risk culture by providing insight into how well actions aimed at promoting the importance, understanding, and awareness of risk culture have progressed. Risk culture assessments consider ANZ's people's perceptions of risk management behaviours and practices, risk and business outcomes, focusing on how risk is considered in its decision-making.
column20: Risk Culture Survey, risk culture, risk management

column6: Role of the highest governance body in sustainability reporting
column13: ANZ's Non-Executive Directors Code recognises the different responsibilities that Directors have under law and enshrines the same values and principles as the Employee Code. The Code requires honesty, integrity, quality and trust.
column20: Non-Executive Directors Code, Director, integrity, quality

column13: ANZ promotes a Risk Culture Toolkit to raise awareness and support actions to embed its targeted risk culture. It includes ethical scenarios that support embedding ANZ's targeted risk culture behaviours, risk culture self-assessment templates for people leaders, and training materials for leaders to raise awareness of risk culture meaningfully.
column20: Risk Culture Toolkit, awareness, risk culture, ethical scenario

column13: ANZ has a Directors' Disclosure of Interest, Handling Conflicts of Interest and Outside Commitments Procedure. It provides that a Director must not allow a conflict of interest to compromise their position as a Director of the Company.
column20: Disclosure of Interest, Handling Conflicts of Interest and Outside Commitments Procedure, conflict of interest

column13: The Whistleblower Policy and Program is a key component of ANZ's strong and effective conduct risk management and corporate governance framework. ANZ applies Australian whistleblower regulations across the markets where it operates. Additional jurisdiction-specific regulations imposing higher or contrary obligations are captured in schedules within the Policy.
column20: Whistleblower Policy, risk management, corporate governance

column6: Collective knowledge of the highest governance body
column13: During the year, the NBO Committee reviewed and reassessed the approach to the Board Skills Matrix. Utilising the approach of an external expert, each Director participated in a self-assessment of their levels of capability and experience in 60 different areas, grouped into 10 categories.
column20: Board Skills Matrix, external expert, self-assessment

column6: Evaluation of the performance of the highest governance body
column13: ANZ conducts performance evaluations of each Non-Executive Director, the Chairman of the Board, the Board and the Board Committees. Upon recommendation from the Board Chairman, the NBO Committee will annually determine the process to be followed in assessing Non-Executive Directors, Boards and Board Committees, taking account of regulatory requirements in this area.
column20: Performance evaluation, Non-Executive Director, regulatory requirement

column13: The Board approves the ANZ Group Performance Framework at the start of each year. It plays a key role in messaging internally what matters most, reinforcing the importance of sound management in addition to risk, financial, customer, and people outcomes, and informing focus of effort, prioritisation and decision-making across ANZ.
column20: ANZ Group Performance Framework, decision making, people outcome

column7: In structuring remuneration, the Board aims to find the right balance between fixed and variable remuneration (at risk), the way it is delivered (cash versus deferred remuneration) and appropriate deferral time frames (the short, medium and long-term).
Variable remuneration for the CEO and the Disclosed Executives include STVR as 50% cash and 50% shares deferred equally over years 2 and 3.

"We are more resilient than ever before and have the right portfolio balance, leadership team and strategy in place, underpinned by a highly engaged, diverse workforce and a purpose-led culture. I want to thank the team at ANZ for their efforts. As CEO, I am pleased with our progress and look forward to continued momentum across our businesses in the years ahead."

column13: Risk culture is an important component of ANZ's organisational culture and underpins the shared values, behaviours and practices that influence how risk is considered in decision-making. Significant progress has been made in strengthening risk culture, with the Group achieving its target state. The Board and executive leadership teams have emphasised the importance of risk culture, providing strong leadership and oversight. It has resulted in outcomes that have further embedded ANZ's target risk behaviours and uplifted risk management in several key focus areas Ã¢ÂÂ particularly the group-wide non-financial risk framework.
column20: Risk culture, organisational culture, shared value

column13: ANZ's Risk Management Strategy describes the approach for managing risk arising from the Group's purpose and strategy. The RMS includes how the Risk function is structured to support the Group's purpose and strategy and the execution of the Group Chief Risk Officer's prescribed responsibilities as an Accountable Person for ANZBGL under the Banking Executive Accountability Regime.
column20: Risk Management Strategy, Chief Risk Officer, Accountable Person

column13: ANZ's Extra Care Hub is a specialist team that supports frontline staff. It has a focus on supporting customers impacted by family violence and financial abuse through early intervention and reviewing and making changes to their banking arrangements to limit potential harm. The Hub has helped support 800 cases this year.
column20: Extra Care Hub, frontline staff, family violence
